abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Fifty years after the recognition of the Li–Fraumeni syndrome (LFS), our perception of cancers related to germline alterations of <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> has drastically changed: (i) germline <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> alterations are often identified among children with cancers, in particular soft-tissue sarcomas, adrenocortical carcinomas, central nervous system tumours, or among adult females with early breast cancers, without familial history. This justifies the expansion of the LFS concept to a wider cancer predisposition syndrome designated heritable <jats:italic>TP53-</jats:italic>related cancer (h<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>rc) syndrome; (ii) the interpretation of germline <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> variants remains challenging and should integrate epidemiological, phenotypical, bioinformatics prediction, and functional data; (iii) the penetrance of germline disease-causing <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> variants is variable, depending both on the type of variant (dominant-negative variants being associated with a higher cancer risk) and on modifying factors; (iv) whole-body MRI (WBMRI) allows early detection of tumours in variant carriers and (v) in cancer patients with germline disease-causing <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> variants, radiotherapy, and conventional genotoxic chemotherapy contribute to the development of subsequent primary tumours. It is critical to perform <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> testing before the initiation of treatment in order to avoid in carriers, if possible, radiotherapy and genotoxic chemotherapies. In children, the recommendations are to perform clinical examination and abdominal ultrasound every 6 months, annual WBMRI and brain MRI from the first year of life, if the <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> variant is known to be associated with childhood cancers. In adults, the surveillance should include every year clinical examination, WBMRI, breast MRI in females from 20 until 65 years and brain MRI until 50 years.</jats:p>
